resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:173692724</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:WHi</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>National Association of Educational Broadcasters.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Association of College and University Broadcasting Stations.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Records, 1925-1977.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Records, mainly 1950-1970, of an association of educational broadcasters and public broadcasting stations. The NAEB traced its origins to the formation of the Association of College and University Broadcasting Stations in 1925. The records include correspondence, reports, clippings, speeches of long-time president William G. Harley, files of the Office of Research and Development and of National Educational Radio (a division of the NAEB), and a newsletter and small publication file. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Records, 1925-1977.
resource.abstract: Records, mainly 1950-1970, of an association of educational broadcasters and public broadcasting stations. The NAEB traced its origins to the formation of the Association of College and University Broadcasting Stations in 1925. The records include correspondence, reports, clippings, speeches of long-time president William G. Harley, files of the Office of Research and Development and of National Educational Radio (a division of the NAEB), and a newsletter and small publication file.
resource.extent: 44.2 c.f. (112 archives boxes)3 tape recordings, and.21 photographs.
resource.displayEntry: National Association of Educational Broadcasters. Records, 1925-1977.

originationNames.name: Association of College and University Broadcasting Stations.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Mass Media and Culture</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>Special Collections, University of Maryland Libraries, Hornbake Library, College Park, MD 20742. Tel: 301-405-9212, Fax: 301-314-2709, Email: askhornbake@umd.edu</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>Steetle, Ralph W.</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>Ralph W. Steetle Papers</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1942-1981</unitdate>
                  <unitdate>1950-1958</unitdate>
                  <physdesc>2.50 linear feet</physdesc>
                  <unitid>NPBA 93-38</unitid>
                  <physloc>Room 3210 (Showcase Room):70:B:Room 3210 (Showcase Room) 70 : B : </physloc>
                  <abstract>Ralph Steetle began in educational radio at Louisiana State University where he was its director of broadcasting, and helped build WLSU, one of the first educational FM stations in the south.  In the early 1950s, he volunteered to work for the Joint Council on Educational Television (JCET) as an associate director, but became its executive director when Richard Hull left.  The Joint Council on Educational Television served as an advocate organization for all the channels.  While working for JCET, Steetle worked on the FCC Third Report and Order.  This report tentatively set aside 209 frequencies, and became the Sixth Report of 1952, which then allowed 209 communities to speak to the FCC. The collection chronicles the early history of the Joint Committee on Educational Television and Steetle's involvement in this organization.</abstract>
                  <abstract>Ralph Steetle began in educational radio at Louisiana State University where he was its director of broadcasting, and helped build WLSU, one of the first educational FM stations in the south.  In the early 1950s, he volunteered to work for the Joint Council on Educational Television (JCET) as an associate director, but became its executive director when Richard Hull left.  The Joint Council on Educational Television served as an advocate organization for all the channels.  While working for JCET, Steetle worked on the FCC Third Report and Order.  This report tentatively set aside 209 frequencies, and became the Sixth Report of 1952, which then allowed 209 communities to speak to the FCC. The collection chronicles the early history of the Joint Committee on Educational Television and Steetle's involvement in this organization.</abstract>
                  <abstract>Ralph Steetle began in educational radio at Louisiana State University where he was its director of broadcasting, and helped build WLSU, one of the first educational FM stations in the south.  In the early 1950s, he volunteered to work for the Joint Council on Educational Television (JCET) as an associate director, but became its executive director when Richard Hull left.  The Joint Council on Educational Television served as an advocate organization for all the channels.  While working for JCET, Steetle worked on the FCC Third Report and Order.  This report tentatively set aside 209 frequencies, and became the Sixth Report of 1952, which then allowed 209 communities to speak to the FCC. The collection chronicles the early history of the Joint Committee on Educational Television and Steetle's involvement in this organization.</abstract>
                  <abstract>Ralph Steetle began in educational radio at Louisiana State University where he was its director of broadcasting, and helped build WLSU, one of the first educational FM stations in the south.  In the early 1950s, he volunteered to work for the Joint Council on Educational Television (JCET) as an associate director, but became its executive director when Richard Hull left.  The Joint Council on Educational Television served as an advocate organization for all the channels.  While working for JCET, Steetle worked on the FCC Third Report and Order.  This report tentatively set aside 209 frequencies, and became the Sixth Report of 1952, which then allowed 209 communities to speak to the FCC. The collection chronicles the early history of the Joint Committee on Educational Television and Steetle's involvement in this organization.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Ralph W. Steetle Papers 1942-1981 1950-1958
resource.abstract: Ralph Steetle began in educational radio at Louisiana State University where he was its director of broadcasting, and helped build WLSU, one of the first educational FM stations in the south.  In the early 1950s, he volunteered to work for the Joint Council on Educational Television (JCET) as an associate director, but became its executive director when Richard Hull left.  The Joint Council on Educational Television served as an advocate organization for all the channels.  While working for JCET, Steetle worked on the FCC Third Report and Order.  This report tentatively set aside 209 frequencies, and became the Sixth Report of 1952, which then allowed 209 communities to speak to the FCC. The collection chronicles the early history of the Joint Committee on Educational Television and Steetle's involvement in this organization. Ralph Steetle began in educational radio at Louisiana State University where he was its director of broadcasting, and helped build WLSU, one of the first educational FM stations in the south.  In the early 1950s, he volunteered to work for the Joint Council on Educational Television (JCET) as an associate director, but became its executive director when Richard Hull left.  The Joint Council on Educational Television served as an advocate organization for all the channels.  While working for JCET, Steetle worked on the FCC Third Report and Order.  This report tentatively set aside 209 frequencies, and became the Sixth Report of 1952, which then allowed 209 communities to speak to the FCC. The collection chronicles the early history of the Joint Committee on Educational Television and Steetle's involvement in this organization. In the early 1950s, he volunteered to work for the Joint Council on Educational Television (JCET) as an associate director, but became its executive director when Richard Hull left.  The Joint Council on Educational Television served as an advocate organization for all the channels.  While working for JCET, Steetle worked on the FCC Third Report and Order.  This report tentatively set aside 209 frequencies, and became the Sixth Report of 1952, which then allowed 209 communities to speak to the FCC. The collection chronicles the early history of the Joint Committee on Educational Television and Steetle's involvement in this organization. Ralph Steetle began in educational radio at Louisiana State University where he was its director of broadcasting, and helped build WLSU, one of the first educational FM stations in the south.  In the early 1950s, he volunteered to work for the Joint Council on Educational Television (JCET) as an associate director, but became its executive director when Richard Hull left.  The Joint Council on Educational Television served as an advocate organization for all the channels.  While working for JCET, Steetle worked on the FCC Third Report and Order.  This report tentatively set aside 209 frequencies, and became the Sixth Report of 1952, which then allowed 209 communities to speak to the FCC. The collection chronicles the early history of the Joint Committee on Educational Television and Steetle's involvement in this organization.
